content.description: <math alttext="2 H 2 S, gas, plus S O 2, gas, is in equilibrium with 3 S, solid, plus 2 H 2 O, gas, where delta H of reaction is less than 0, and delta G of reaction is less than 0 at 298 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable><mtr><mtd><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>SO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded></mpadded></mtd><mtd></mtd></mtr></mtable><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>H</mi><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>and</mtext><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>G</mi><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>at</mtext><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>298 K</mtext></math>
content.question: A <math alttext="0.20 mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.20</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mol</mi></math> sample of <math alttext="H 2 S, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> and a <math alttext="0.10 mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.10</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mol</mi></math> sample of <math alttext="S O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>SO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> are placed in a previously evacuated <math alttext="10.0 liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></math> vessel at <math alttext="298 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>298</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>. Even though the reaction represented by the equation above is thermodynamically favorable, the formation of <math alttext="S, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> was not observed. Which of the following best explains why <math alttext="S, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is not produced at <math alttext="298 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>298</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>?

choices.label: At <math alttext="298 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>298</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>, some <math alttext="S, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> must first be present for the reaction to occur.

At <math alttext="298 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>298</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>, the value of the equilibrium constant is less than 1.

At <math alttext="298 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>298</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>, the energy of most molecular collisions is lower than the activation energy for the reaction.

At <math alttext="298 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>298</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>, the loss of entropy is too great to make molecular collisions likely to occur.

content.answer: At <math alttext="298 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>298</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>, the energy of most molecular collisions is lower than the activation energy for the reaction.

skill.text: 4.D: Explain the degree to which a model or representation describes the connection between particulate-level properties and macroscopic properties.
